member.name: T:Microsoft.ApplicationServer.Http.Channels.HttpMessageHandlerFactory
member.summary: Default HTTP message handler factory for instantiating a set of HTTP message handler types using their default constructors.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ApplicationServer.Http.Channels.HttpMessageHandlerFactory.#ctor(System.Type[])
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class given a set of HTTP message handler types to instantiate using their default constructors.
member.param: An ordered list of HTTP message handler types to be invoked as part of an instance. HTTP message handler types must derive from and have a public constructor taking exactly one argument of type . The handlers are invoked in a bottom-up fashion in the incoming path and top-down in the outgoing path. That is, the last entry is called first for an incoming request message but invoked last for an outgoing response message.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class given a used to create a set of instances.
member.param: A function to generate an ordered list of instances to be invoked as part of an instance. The handlers are invoked in a bottom-up fashion in the incoming path and top-down in the outgoing path. That is, the last entry is called first for an incoming request message but invoked last for an outgoing response message.

this method returns one string with special structures to present one autocomplete entry to javascript client the structure is display-name
value
replace-start-position
final-caret-pos
applicable
e.g. if request is: <ab| then one autocomplete entry might look like: MyElement
MyElement></MyElement>
-2
-12
true in dropdown list, it looks like: MyElement after replacement, it looks like: <MyElement>|</MyElement>
member.param: mandatory, used as <option> name, and also used as sorting key
mandatory, used as <option> value (i.e. for replacement into textbox), and also used as tooltip

mandatory, when provided, this is the relative position to the current-pos in the request meaning where replacement in textbox should start; when omitted, javascript should use its own logic to find replace start position

optional, when provided, this is the relative position to the replace end position meaning where caret should be after replacement and will trigger another autocomplete; when omitted, javascript should do nothing i.e. caret stays at the end of replacement in textbox
optional, when provided, this means whether this <option> item should be grayed out; when omitted, javascript should do nothing i.e. the <option> item displays normal
member.returns: one string with special structures to present one autocomplete entry to javascript client
